page.title: 07THATCHING IN HONING
page.content: Buffham's Farm, a listed building on the Honing Estate, is being renovated and re-thatched. On February 8th. we walked to the farm to meet the thatcher. On a bitterly cold day he showed us some of his tools in a small haybarn close to the house- the leggat that neatens the overhang and pushes the reeds firmly down, his knives for cutting reeds and sedge, and his protective leather knee pads. The reed comes from St. Olaves, and the sedge from Catfield a few miles away. We saw him use liggers and brotches. The sedge is used for the ridge of the roof. His company employs three elderly thatchers only. They have no apprentices learning the art so when the three of them retire the company will cease to exist. Few thatched roofs remain, those that do are often the subject of preservation orders.
